awd_titl_txt: CRII:CHS: Addressing Individual Differences in Human-Autonomous Vehicle Interaction in Mixed Transportation Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

Autonomous vehicles will change the way human drivers interact with vehicles dramatically. Before there is 100% adoption of autonomous vehicles (AV), we will have a mixed transportation system in which AVs share the roads with human-driven vehicles (HV).  This project investigates how driving styles of autonomous vehicles impact decision-making, trust, and acceptance of AVs both for the human operator and for human drivers in other vehicles. This project will benefit the design of AVs to promote drivers' trust of AVs in mixed traffic conditions, mitigate driver aggressiveness to improve driver safety, address public acceptance of autonomous vehicles, and smooth the transition into a future where autonomous driving is prevalent. It provides researchers and urban policy-makers knowledge and methods to evaluate the effects of AV technology on mixed transportation systems. This research will support the development of graduate-level curricula integrating research and practical design issues in human-vehicle interaction, providing an interdisciplinary education for students from Industrial Engineering, Civil Engineering, and Mechanical Engineering.
    
This project addresses the transitional period of mixed driving systems that are expected to grow in the coming years by targeting three fundamental questions: (1) how to quantify the relationship between individual differences, trust, and decision-making in the interaction between an AV and the human operator; (2) how to investigate driver behavior and performance in the interaction between AV and human-driven vehicles; and (3) how to design driving styles of autonomous vehicles that can improve driver trust and acceptance of AV technology while mitigating the potential for offsetting behavior (e.g. drivers' tendency of additional risk taking when they feel safer).  Throughout the project, the effects of individual differences in driving style (aggressive vs conservative), the propensity to trust technology, and age, gender, and driving experience are explored empirically.  Corresponding design guidelines of AV driving styles will also be proposed to improve driver safety and promote driver trust of AVs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project provides a better understanding of how different drivers react to and interact with automated vehicles (AVs) based on their individual driving styles. To this end, human-subject studies were conducted with drivers exhibiting varying driving styles, from defensive and moderate to aggressive. These studies assessed drivers' trust, acceptance, decision-making, and behaviors in both intra-vehicle and inter-vehicle interactions. Additionally, drivers? perceptions of significant maneuvers of automated driving styles have been identified. Lastly, models were developed to quantify the relationships among the alignment of drivers' and AVs' driving styles, driver perceived safety, trust, acceptance, and decision-making in human-AV interactions.

Key outcomes of this project include the following:

First, this work underscores the importance of carefully designing automated driving maneuvers to align with driver expectations for drivers riding with AVs. Specifically, when the AV's driving style matches the driver's own, trust and acceptance are enhanced, reducing undesired takeover behavior.

Secondly, the research suggests that drivers interact differently with AVs and human-driven vehicles, depending on their driving styles. Aggressive and moderate drivers tend to make more aggressive decisions when interacting with AVs than with human-driven vehicles. These findings reveal an increased risk-taking tendency with the introduction of AVs, potentially diminishing the safety benefits of AV technologies. This provides a basis for policymakers to regulate driver behaviors in mixed traffic to ensure a smooth transition and improved transportation safety.

Thirdly, the work demonstrates that overly aggressive or excessively defensive driving behaviors in automated vehicle can be perceived as inappropriate by human drivers. Specifically, drivers' trust and acceptance of AVs decrease if they perceived the vehicles to exhibit higher speeds, larger decelerations, smaller decelerations, or shorter stopping distances than anticipated. These results identify human-perception-sensitive maneuvers for designing automated driving styles.

Fourthly, this study quantifies the relationships between AV and driver driving styles, perceived inappropriateness of automated driving maneuvers, perceived safety, trust, acceptance, and decision-making. Factors such as trust propensity, interaction effect between AVs? and drivers? driving styles, and perceived inappropriateness significantly influence drivers' trust in AVs. Trust and perceived safety during AV driving, in turn, significantly impact drivers' acceptance and decision-making. These results offer new insights into the role of human individual differences and perceived safety in promoting driver trust and acceptance of technology in human-automation interactions.

Fifth, this work resulted in a series of case studies on human-automation interaction in engineering education. Lastly, this project has produced several archival publications documenting the above outcomes, enabling future researchers and practitioners to build upon or leverage these findings.
